nodes.title: ai4artsed_text_prompt
widgets_values: Ein Banner mit der Aufschrift ACHTUNG DEFAULT-PROMPT!

nodes.title: How to use this template
widgets_values:
Nach dem Öffnen direkt im Menü am unteren Bildrand: "Workflow -> Save as"
speichern als 

DeinSelbstgewähltesKürzel_WORKFLOW-NAME_timecode  (timecode = JahrMonatTagStundeMinute, z.B. 2506100949)

z.B. BenJoe_SCHERENSCHNITT_2506100953

Neue Versionen: einfach "Save as" und den timecode anpassen.

Das originale Template sicherheitshalber schließen (untere Bildrand, Reiter -> X - Zeichen). Alle unsere Workflows sind gesichert; Ihr könnt also nicht wichtiges löschen! ;-)

Wenn Euer Workflow im "Werkraum" eingestellt werden soll, gebt uns bitte Bescheid!
A banner showing DEFAULT PROMPT, EINGABE FEHLGESCHLAGEN

nodes.title: Interceptive context - REPLACE THIS AS YOU SEE FIT (default is meant for the AI4ArtsEd web-interface)
Former trasnlation prompt w/o relational analysis
widgets_values:
Translate the prompt into English with maximal semantic preservation. If it is already in English, do not change the input.

Preserve the original structure and formatting. Maintain the exact order and punctuation of the input wherever possible.

Do not translate or modify:
- Proper names
- Ritual terms
- Material names
unless there is a widely used English equivalent.

Mark such culturally specific or untranslated terms using double square brackets (e.g. [[egungun]]) and leave them in their original position.

Do not paraphrase, interpret, summarize, or rephrase. Do not add any comments, notes, or explanations.

Return only the translated prompt as plain text output, with no extra text.

nodes.title: Choose your checkpoint ( = image generation model)
Just a more convenient input for your prompt
widgets_values: A white rooster standing on a green goat standing on a red cat standing on a black dog.

nodes.title: AI4ArtsEd Translation and relational analysis
widgets_values:
Translate the prompt into English with maximal semantic preservation. If it is already in English, do not change the input.

Preserve the original structure and formatting. Maintain the exact order and punctuation of the input wherever possible.

Do not translate or modify:
- Proper names
- Ritual terms
- Material names
unless there is a widely used English equivalent.

Mark such culturally specific or untranslated terms using double square brackets (e.g. [[egungun]]) and leave them in their original position.

Translate the input into english.
Analyze the input and output exactly two separate tables. Do not include any introductory or explanatory text beyond these tables.
First Table: Visually Observable Entities and Relationships
Format:
| Entity 1 | Relation | Entity 2 | Relation Type |
Instructions:
1. Identify all visible or implied entities (people, objects, animals, symbols, elements of the environment, etc.).
2. For each pair of entities, specify a concrete relation that connects them using clear, unambiguous terms (e.g., "above", "next to", "inside", "wearing", "has color").
3. Classify each relation into one of the following types:
- spatial (e.g., above, next to, inside)
- temporal (e.g., before, after, simultaneous)
- causal (e.g., causes, enables, prevents)
- symbolic (e.g., represents, connotes, expresses)
- narrative (e.g., protagonist of, is acted upon by, interacts with)
- social (e.g., mother of, enemy of, supports)
- property (e.g., has color, has gender, has age, shows emotion)
Second Table: Inferred or Interpretative Semantic Relations
Format:
| Subject | Inferred Relation | Object / Value | Type | Source |
Instructions:
1. Extract higher-level, inferred semantic relations based on visual cues and contextual hints. These relations can include emotional states, narrative context, symbolic meanings, social dynamics, environmental impressions, temporal cues, or attentional focus.
2. For each inference, specify the relation clearly and classify it using one of the following types: emotional, narrative, symbolic, social, environmental, temporal, attentional, or other.
3. In the “Source” column, indicate the origin of the inference (e.g., "visual cue", "contextual inference", "cultural trope", "associative logic").
4. Use one row per relation.
Output only the two markdown tables in the specified format.

Transform the image description according to the logic and instructions defined in the input labeled “input_context”.
This is not a linguistic translation, but a semantic and structural transformation.
Reconstruct all entities and their relations as specified, ensuring that:
- The whole description is turned into its opposite. Everything is upside-down, inside-out, turned around.
- The resulting structure reflects a complete semantic inversion.
Do not explain your reasoning.
Output only the transformed description, either as structured data (if input was structured), or as plain descriptive text (if input was textual).

Transform the following input text—regardless of genre—into a single, uninterrupted paragraph structured for encoding by a T5 model and subsequent conditioning of a Stable Diffusion 3.5 (or Flux1) image generation model.

RULES:
Your input in probably unconventional. Do not align or straighten-out unconventional relations and pictures, but support the logical relations of the input whatsoever.
Do translate content into a visual depiction/description. Do not add or translate content unless an exact transliteration or orthographic variant is supplied in the source. YOUR OUTPUT IS ABSOLUTELY FOCUSED ON PROVIDING DETAILED VISUAL INSTRUCTIONS FOR A VISUAL SCENE.

GUIDANCE:
Consider the following categories as guideline for your professional prompting process:
- Core subject : Identify and foreground the principal subject matter as fully specified in the source.
- Action : Preserve any dynamic, procedural, or temporal structures, expressed clearly through grammatically embedded verb phrases.
- Relational context : Expand on spatial relations, historical or cultural frameworks, ecological configurations, embodied perspectives, and temporal situatedness, all inferred from internal content only.
- Attributive qualities : Elaborate sensory and atmospheric descriptors—light, surface, sound, temperature, tactility, material behaviour—based on concrete and culturally situated evidence. Avoid cliché mappings such as “melancholy → rain” or “futurism → neon.” Do not use general affective adjectives such as “beautiful,” “epic,” or “highly detailed.” Instead, convey mood through spatial structure, material traces, or historical signifiers.
- Material, stylistic and medial references : If applicable, retain or clarify materialities (pictorial mediality), stylistic provenance using historically anchored terms (e.g., “early Bauhaus sketch,” “Qing-dynasty monochrome ink”). Avoid genre tropes unless explicitly included in the original text.
- Technical parameters : Place any camera data, aspect ratio at the end of the prompt. Use these codes to communicate technical instructions:
   
   
Additional requirements:
– If the source uses conflicting descriptors (e.g., “nocturnal daylight”), preserve both and separate with a slash ( / ) to indicate intentional contradiction.
– If vague temporal expressions appear (e.g., “ancient”), translate them into relative or historical chronologies only if unambiguous context exists.

Final output must be exactly one paragraph, without bullet points, tags, headings, or formatting cues.

!YOUR OUTPUT MUST NOT EXCEED 55 WORDS!

NO META-REMARKS ABOUT PROMPT; WORD COUNTS ETC!

groups.title: ai4artsed standard prompt input and translation
